Title: Creating JSON Web Tokens using dotnet user-jwts tool
Description: This post is about creating JSON Web Tokens in development with dotnet user-jwts CLI tool. This tool introduced last year - recently I saw some demo using this tool and it was awesome. So I explored it and started using it in projects. The dotnet user-jwts command line tool can create and manage app specific local JSON Web Tokens (JWTs).

Title: Tagged Strings in Visual Studio and .NET 7
Description: As part of .NET 7, developers now have the ability to tag strings using the StringSyntax attribute. These tags inform tools such as Visual Studio as to the nature of the string. For example, you can mark the string as containing JSON or RegEx and Visual Studio will apply the appropriate syntax highlighting.

Title: Cloud-Native Application Security - DZone Refcardz
Description: This Refcard introduces the critical components of cloud-native application security, how to build security into the CI/CD pipeline, and core patterns and anti-patterns.

Title: How to publish .NET 7 apps directly to Docker
Description:
With .NET 7 being around for only a couple of days now, there are plenty of new features to be played with.
One of these is the actual ability of .NET's build infrastructure to directly publish your applications to a Docker container registry (or any other container registry, for that matter), without having to explicitly specify a Docker file.

Title: Lambda Cold Starts - .NET 7 Native AOT vs .NET 6 Managed Runtime | no dogma blog
Description: The release of .NET 7 brings with it a new way to compile and run .NET code - native AOT compilation. This post compares the cold start time of a Lambda function running on .NET 7 after native AOT compilation with the cold start time of a Lambda function running on .NET 6 with the managed runtime. The results are surprisingly good.

Title: ECMAScript proposal: source text access for `JSON.parse()` and `JSON.stringify()`
Description: In this blog post, we look at the ECMAScript proposal “JSON.parse source text access” by Richard Gibson and Mathias Bynens. It gives access to source text to two kinds of callbacks: Revivers, callbacks that are passed to JSON.parse() and post-process the data it parses. Replacers, callbacks that are passed to JSON.stringify() and pre-process data before it is stringified. We’ll examine how exactly that works and what you can do with this feature.

Title: Nix By Example | <fun>
Description: To "nixify" a project, it only needs a flake.nix file at its root. To create one, you can use the nix flake new command.

Title: Technical Challenges of Scale at Twitter
Description: We take a peak into some of the challenges Twitter has faced while solving data problems at large scale, while Michael challenges the audience, Joe speaks from experience, and Allen blindsides them both.

Title: A Life Engineered
Description:
Software engineers can make code do just about anything. However, they often struggle with career direction, work-life balance and finding true meaning in their jobs.

Am I hitting a bit close to home? 

Let’s change that.

I have 16 years of experience at a high-performance, high-stress FAANG company as a principal engineer (top 1%). I’ve conducted over 850 technical interviews and am an expert on the promotion/growth track for high-level, non-managerial tech leadership.

It’s time to learn how to give your career and your life the same impact that your programs create for others. I’ll be there to guide you, prod you and maybe even push you out of your comfort zone. 

Ready to take a smart engineering approach to your career and life? 

Let’s do this.
